lines.text: Nowhere in all fiction can be found more romance than was crowded into the life of this penniless commoner, whose natural charm and studied insolence made him the greatest dandy of all time - the immortal "Beau" Brummel.
My heart is all I have to offer - and that I lay in the hollow of your little hand.
Egad, sir, what a beautiful woman!
Your wife has just been kissed - she has never been kissed by a gentleman before.
Did my wife have the honor, sir, of being insulted by you - - or the Prince of Wales?
You can say anything you like about the Prince - but be careful of my reputation.
By George! You're a better beau than I am - George!
By George! I believe I am - George!
I should like to ask Your Royal Highness' permission to resign from the Army?
Have you no wish to serve your country?
Not in Manchester, sir.
His house in London was the rendezvous of the smart world. The dandies of the town flocked to his dressing room to learn the latest scandal or the latest style.
Mortimer, when is your master going to pay me?
I have no master, Mr. Abrahams. I am a Gentleman's gentleman.
Will you arrange a little supper for tonight, George, and invite some friends of the female persuasion - say at eight?
Make it eight-thirty.
My dear Lady Hester, will you do me the honor to marry me when you are free?
[Lady Hester leans in to embrace Beau]
But - if you accept me - I shall hate you like the devil! A divorce and remarriage would hurt my position at court.
What do we care for scandal? You do love me!
I love you more in this moment than ever before - - when I tell you that I have never loved you at all.
Fool! Do you think I care about anything but my own position at court?
Thank you. You have saved me from doing something commonplace.
Mr. Brummel, you are wasting yourself. You have the qualities of a great leader, yet you choose to play the part of court jester.
I am a nobody without rank or fortune. I attract attention by insolence and hold it by scandal.

Things would have been different, Your Royal Highness, had I known the tenderness of a real woman. A woman to sit beside my fire, to move among my things - to bless them with her touch. A woman like Your Royal Highness!
You must listen to me - I have loved but one woman in my life. I loved you then - I love you now - I'll love you always!
But - Lady Hester?
I was lonely - she was amusing.
And - the Duchess?
I was lonely - she was kind.
I have decided to send my good friend, Mr. Brummel, to France, as Ambassador. Frankly, we are tired of our dear Beau's scandals - but scandal is all the rage in France.
I shall be quite fashionable in Calais - spending my time *between* London and Paris.
Death kills but once - Life kills many times.

[Final lines]
Were it the last drop in the cup of life, I would pause to drink - to you.
